journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Analysis of the pressure distribution in spline couplings

article-meta.aff: Dipartimento di Meccanica, Politecnico di Torino, Torin, Italy

author-notes.corresp: Andrea Mura, Dipartimento di Meccanica, Politecnico di Torino, Corso Duca degli Abruzzi 24 – 10129 Torino, Italy. Email: andrea.mura@polito.it

abstract.p: Spline couplings used in aerospace applications, supporting very high specific power, need an accurate design in order to reduce the weight and to avoid failure mechanisms as fretting fatigue. One of the influence parameters of this kind of phenomena is the pressure distribution on the teeth surface. In this article, the pressure distribution on spline coupling teeth has been investigated by means of analytical approaches and experimental techniques. In particular, the contact pressure distribution between the teeth in axial direction, obtained by means of analytical models available in literature, has been compared with both experimental data and finite element method models. The experimental pressure distribution has been obtained thanks to a special film, capable of changing colour intensity with the pressure variation, and a dedicated software relating the colour intensity to the pressure level. A dedicated workbench has been set-up and a special spline shaft has been created in order to well fit the pressure measurements.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Spline couplings are mechanical devices commonly used to join two shafts in torque transmission lines.
In particular, spline couplings used in aerospace applications need more accurate design in order to reduce the weight and to avoid failure mechanisms as fretting fatigue.1
Damage phenomena as both fretting corrosion and fretting fatigue may be influenced by many factors; one of the most important is the load distribution, expressed in terms of contact pressure.2

As a matter of fact, if the pressure distribution map (combined with other factors as relative sleep) along the teeth contact surface is known, it is possible to predict where the fretting could be appear.3
As referred in literature,4 it may be observed that the pressure distribution on the teeth is non-uniform and substantially different in radial and axial directions.

By considering an ideal spline (without manufacturing errors), this pressure distribution depends on the stiffness of both tooth and shaft and also depends on the loading configurations (loading case where power crosses the assembly and opposite one power does not cross the assembly).
Many theoretical studies about pressure distribution are available in literature.4
Different analytical approaches may be identified: Tatur and Vygonnyi,5 Orain,6 Volfson,7 Blanc8 and Barrot et al.9–11

Tatur’s5 model allows to determine the distribution of axial load without assuming a constant value for the concentration ratio of the contact pressure and still considering the influence of torsional stiffness of shaft and hub.

Orain’s6 model considers the axial load distribution in order to obtain uniform distribution of contact pressure in the axial direction while maintaining the constancy of the second moment of area and the polar moment of the bodies.

Volfson’s7 model allows to evaluate the influence of the relative ratio between the torsional stiffness of shaft and hub related to the axial pressure; the basis hypothesis is to consider the radial distribution of the contact pressure parabolic and the value of the concentration ratio of the pressure fixed.

Blanc’s8 approach, representing a refinement of the above quoted models, is based on a simplified finite element method (FEM) model (one-dimensional). In particular, it has been considered a complex geometry corresponding to a spline coupling having variable both inner diameter of the shaft and outer diameter of the hub.

Barrot et al.9–11 completed the study about load distribution on the spline coupling teeth surface, presenting a model for calculating both radial and axial pressure distributions, and torsional stiffness, considering also the effect of the second moment of area.

Analytical models previously described have been only verified by means of numerical models; as an example in the case of Barrot,9 coefficients of the model have been calculated and benchmarked only referring to a FEM model.
On the other hand, experimental analyses are very rare, because of the difficulties to perform pressure distribution measurements on a spline coupling.

Adey et al.12 measured the torsional tooth root stress by means of photoelastic models and strain gauges, but they did not perform any contact stress measurement; moreover, the contact condition between steel spline and photoelastic material is very different.12–14

Also Gamez-Montero et al.15 made photoelastic tests on a trochoidal gear to evaluate stresses at the contact point, but they found problems related to the lack of precision of the technique at the zone very closed to the contact area and related to the scale of the model.

Guingand et al.16 studied a procedure for analysing the instantaneous loaded contact and they performed an experimental validation using strain gauges. The problem of this experimental set-up was the complexity of the system and the discrete measurement (it was possible to measure only few points).

In fact, the experimental evaluation of the contact pressure distribution in spline couplings is very difficult, but analytical models need an experimental validation to make realistic the calculated values.

The object of this study is the analysis of the pressure distribution in spline couplings from both experimental and analytical/numerical point of view. To do that, first a measure methodology has been developed.

In particular a dedicated testbed generating a constant torque in the spline coupling, has been designed and set-up. To overcome the difficulties in measuring the pressure distribution by means of normal pressure sensors, a special pressure sensitive film has been utilised. This special film change its colour pattern according to the change of pressure level. A dedicated software allows to obtain the pressure map from the colour pattern.

An apposite test article has been designed, in order to make pressure measurements. This test article is a spline coupling having an high tooth modulus and a tooth profile shifted in order to allow positioning of the pressure film between the teeth.

Then, the experimental results have been used to verify the analytical solutions developed in Barrot et al.9–11 In particular, the coefficients related to the analytical models9–11 have been compared and optimised.

Finally, numerical FEM simulations have been executed to complete the analysis; the obtained results, in terms of pressure distribution in axial direction, have been compared to both experimental and analytical ones.

sec.title: Experimental set-up
sec.p:
A dedicated device (see Figure 1) has been designed and manufactured in order to apply a pure static torque to the spline coupling in non-crossing load condition. Figure 1.
Experimental device: photo (left) and design (right).

This device is constituted by a fixed flange connecting the sleeve and a rotating flange connecting the shaft; the load is applied to the rotating flange by means of a lever carrying calibrated weights.
Pressure distribution has been measured by means of a commercial film (FujiFilm Prescale®), interposed between two engaging teeth.
The Prescale® film may change its colour density according to the pressure level; being extremely thin (0.2 mm), it may be interposed in the gap between two teeth of the spline coupling.

Film sheet is constituted by a polyester base on which is layered a microencapsulated colour-forming material and a layer of colour developing material. When a pressure is applied, the microcapsules are broken and the colour-forming reacts with the colour-developing material; so, red patches appear on the film. Because of the morphology of this kind of pressure film, it is possible to perform only static measurements. The corresponding image of the colour patch is then acquired by a scanner and analysed by a dedicated software (FPT8010E) converting the colour density in a pressure magnitude.

Two types of Prescale® film have been utilised: LLLW and LLW films, respectively, measuring 0.2–0.5 and 0.5–2.5 MPa pressure ranges.14 The typical accuracy is ±10% at 23 °C and 65% relative humidity (RH).17
The room temperature during the tests was 23 °C and the humidity was 43% RH.

Test article is a spline coupling with a calibrated gap between teeth in order to allow the pressure film application (Figure 2). Figure 2.
Positioning of the pressure film.

From Table 1, it can be seen the spline coupling having a modulus quite large; this was done to facilitate the acquisition of data through the film. Film dimensions are 40 × 8 mm2: this is a good proportion to elaborate the data with the high resolution scanner. Table 1.
Parameters of the spline coupling.
Pitch diameter (mm) 48
Modulus (mm) 8
Number of teeth 6
Pressure angle (°) 30
Shaft external diameter (mm) 53.5
Sleeve internal diameter (mm) 42
Profile shift (mm) 0.5
Material 38NiCrMo4
Characteristics of the test article are shown in Table 1; the dimensions of the spline coupling have been chosen according to the German standard DIN 5480.18

Figure 3 shows both sleeve and shaft of the tested spline coupling. Figure 3.
Sleeve and shaft of the spline coupling.
In order to avoid misalignments, the film has been interposed between two opposite pair of teeth, as shown in Figure 2, so only two teeth engage during the tests.

Two different values for the constant torque have been applied to the spline coupling, respectively, 16.4 and 26.2 Nm. These torque values have been chosen in order to obtain a corresponding pressure distribution between teeth consistent with the measuring range of the film.

sec.title: Analytical model
sec.p: The analytical model used in this study for calculating both radial and axial pressure distributions along the teeth has been developed by Barrot et al.9–11

In particular, the radial pressure distribution has been obtained by an iterative procedure by assuming the Sackfield punch9 as contact model. Because of the variability of the tooth section, the tooth height has been divided into n segments, by modifying the Sackfield punch model to fit the tooth shape.

The expression of the pressure distribution along the contact surface p(sj ) is9 (1)p(sj )=1a2-sj 2(Fπ+αAksj) where F is the contact force, Ak the constant factor, a the half contact length on the curvilinear axis and sj the curvilinear coordinate at node j.

Angle α, representing the teeth distortion, has been calculated9 by considering the superposition of five effects: bending and shear of the teeth, compression, tooth foundation rotation and sliding.9,10 The expression is (2)α=θt e-(θt i+θglob) where θt e and θt i are the, respectively, shaft and sleeve deflection angles determined on the neutral axis and θglob the global rotation angle given by (3)θglob=θb+θs+θc+θf+θsl where θb , θs , θc , θf and θsl are the deformation angles, due, respectively, to bending, shear, compression, tooth foundation rotation and sliding.9

Each contribution of the deformation has a correction factor both for the sleeve and the shaft: Ks for shear and bending, Kc for compression, Ko for rotation of teeth foundation and Kslid for sliding.
The torsional stiffness Cφ may be determined as the ratio between the global rotation angle θglob and the external torque Text applied on the spline coupling9 (4)Cϕ=Textθglob

The expression of the axial pressure distribution p(z) (equation (6)) (in terms of average radial pressure at section z) has been obtained11 starting from Tatur’s19 model and considering into the expression of the transmitted torque m(z) (equation (5)) the torsional stiffness Cφ calculated before9,10 (5)m(z)=dM 2(z)dz=Cϕ(φ1(z)-φ2(z))
(6)p(z)=m(z)cNR=Cϕ(φ1(z)-φ2(z))cNR where M2(z) is the shaft torque (the sum of shaft torque M2(z) and the sleeve torque M1(z) is equal to the external torque), φ1(z) and φ2(z) the, respectively, sleeve and shaft twisting angles, N the number of teeth of the spline coupling, R the pitch radius and c the curvilinear height of tooth.

Input data for the analytical model are resumed in Table 2. Table 2.
Input data for the analytical model.
Shaft Inertia moment (mm4) 251,365
Sleeve Inertia moment (mm4) 879,110
Radial discretisation (number of segments) 2000
Axial discretisation (number of sections) 40
Material 38NiCrMo4
Elastic modulus (MPa) 210,000
Poisson’s ratio 0.3
Contact length (mm) 40
Sleeve and shaft inertial moments have been calculated by a CAD model (software SolidWorks).

sec.title: FEM model
sec.p: A three-dimensional FEM model has been created, by means of the HyperWorks code, in order to determinate the contact pressure distribution between two engaging teeth.

The mesh of the spline coupling, showed in Figure 4, consists in 44,207 hexa elements. The tooth profile is divided into 10 elements along the involute and 35 elements along the axial direction. Figure 4.
FEM models of the spline coupling (a, b). FEM: finite element method.

FEM model has been created, for sake of simplicity, considering only a slice of the coupling consisting in two engaging teeth as shown in Figure 4(a); the whole coupling behaviour is simulated, thanks to its circular symmetry, by connecting the two faces of the shaft slice by means of MPC elements. This kind of elements imposes the same deformation at the two opposite sides.

The teeth’s faces of the hub and shaft in contact have been deliberately stretched to permit the best way to simulate the edge’s effect that is created when the external profiles are not perfectly coincident (Figure 4(b)).

Load is applied on the sleeve and the shaft is clamped. The contact between the teeth is considered merging the two teeth and calculating the hydrostatic pressure, this is valid because of the small strain of the teeth.20

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
The results obtained from the experimental tests, FEM model and analytical model, are reported in the following in terms of contact pressure as a function of the axial position on the face width (see Figure 5). The axial pressure trend, obtained by means of both experimental tests and FEM models, corresponds to the average value of the radial distribution. Figure 5.
Axial and radial positions on the spline coupling.
This average radial pressure may be easily calculated thanks to the distribution of both nodal forces (FEM model) and film values (experimental tests).
Experimental axial pressure has been compared with both analytical and FEM results.

Figure 6(a) shows the film, after it has been impressed by the load, characterised by various shades of magenta colour. Since it is very difficult to distinguish the various shades of colours by the human eye, a special programme has been used to convert the image acquired by a high resolution scanner (with a special algorithm that takes into account internal RH and temperature present during the test), into a pressure map shown in Figure 6(b). Figure 6.
Images of the impressed film before (a) and after elaboration (b).
This new image contains the punctual value of the pressure; this allows to obtain a two-dimensional mapping of the measured pressure.
Experimental pressure values correspond to the average radial ones obtained from the elaboration of the pressure map.

The pressure film has been previously calibrated by means of a dedicated apparatus showed in Figure 7. Figure 7.
Device for pressure film calibration.

The calibration consists in applying a force on a film interposed between two gauge block; the force is measured by means of a load cell. The pressure measured by the film has been multiplied by the contact area to obtain the contact force; this force has been compared with the corresponding determined by the load cell. Obtained results21 are in accordance with the pressure film specification,17 giving 10% as maximum difference between the measured forces.

Figures 8 and 9 show the axial pressure distributions obtained by means of the experimental set-up, the analytical model and the FEM model, respectively for 16.4 and 26.2 Nm torque. Figure 8.
Comparison between experimental, analytical and FEM contact pressure (16.4 Nm torque). FEM: finite element method.
Figure 9.
Comparison between experimental, analytical and FEM contact pressure (26.2 Nm torque). FEM: finite element method.

It may be observed that the pressure distribution presents two characteristic zones: one zone showing a pressure peak (at the ends of the contact’s zone of the spline coupling) and the other one having a relatively low pressure (low pressure zone).

It may be also emphasised that the overlap between trends (experimental, analytical and FEM) is generally good; however both Figures 8 and 9 also show quite discordant distributions related to particular zones.
On this point, it may be noted that in this article, the first goal is to verify the analytical trends by means of an experimental technique, in order to tune the corresponding correcting factors.
Regarding the FEM’s trend, it presents a concavity slightly less than the analytical model, maintaining overall a good overlap with the experimental ones.
It is possible to notice that the results obtained by means of the FEM model are in good agreement with experimental data.
The analytical pressure values have been obtained by fitting correction factors (Ks, Kc, Ko and Kslid) with experimental data.

These correction factors can heavily modify the pressure curve, as shown in Figure 10, where the pressure distribution has been plotted by varying one by one the four coefficients values. It is possible to observe that the curves change their trend by varying the corresponding coefficients; in particular when the coefficients increase, the peak values decrease and the centre values increase; this is because the area under the curves must be constant. It is also possible to observe that the coefficients most affecting the pressure distribution are, respectively, the compression coefficient Kc and the sliding one Kslid. Figure 10.
Influence of the coefficients on the axial pressure behaviour.

To obtain the values of each coefficient better fitting the experimental curve, each coefficient has been increased, starting from those obtained by Barrot,9 in order to minimise both mean absolute error (MAE) and standard deviation (SD).

As an example, Figure 11 shows the MAE and the SD for the Kslid coefficient; it is possible to observe that by increasing the coefficient value, first both MAE and SD decrease, then the trend tends to increase. Figure 11.
Variation of MAE and SD for the Kslid coefficient. MAE: mean absolute error; SD: standard deviation.
As a consequence of that, the best value to minimise both MAE and SD is Kslid = 0.1.
The other coefficients have been obtained in the same way.

All coefficients values have been obtained both for hub (apex H) and shaft (apex S) in the same way: Ks H = 0.008, Ks S = 0.0094, Kc H = 0.085, Kc S = 0.085, Ko H = 0.086, Ko S = 0.05, Kslid S = 0.1 and Kslid H = 0.1.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, the pressure distribution along the teeth of spline couplings has been analysed, above all from the experimental point of view.
In particular, a new experimental technique presenting a good potentiality has been set-up to make quick and easy tests.
Experimental results have been compared to the corresponding obtained by means of both analytical and FEM models.
Good agreement has been showed between numerical and experimental trends in both low and high contact pressure zones.
Also a good agreement has been observed with respect to the analytical results, once a fitting procedure has been done referring to the model coefficients related to the tooth deformation.

Finally, it may be conclude that the experimental set-up utilised in this research allows us to quantitatively measure the contact pressure in spline couplings and also gives us the possibility of correctly calibrate both analytical and numerical models utilised to that aim.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the Regione Piemonte [D.D.127 - 24/12/2007].

ack.p: Thanks to the Regione Piemonte for the financial support and Avio s.p.a. for the assistance.

rotation of teeth foundation correction factor
